Defense Spending
In 2018, U.S. government sales, excluding foreign military sales, accounted for approximately 68% of total net sales.
Geopolitical events, macroeconomic conditions & legislation enactment such as bills appropriations.
Difficult to predict beyond the near-term.
DoD budget fell in FY 2013, remained essentially flat for FY 2014 and 2015, and increased for FY 2016 to 2019.
New technologies
May be untested or unproven.
Product requirements modification leads to delays, setbacks, cost overruns or product failures diverting attention or resources from other projects.
Nature of Future-Technology: interceptors, space-based sensors, high-energy lasers, hypersonics, and counter-hypersonics.
Required to invest in development prior to award as customers demand more 'mature' and 'proven' solutions.
Nature of Contracts
U.S. government contracts are typically either fixed-priced contracts or cost reimbursement contracts.
Fixed-price contracts represent 61% of backlog, and are predominantly either firm fixed-price (FFP) contracts or fixed-price incentive (FPI) contracts.
Major source of loss: fixed-price development contracts.
Classified programs limits discussion of performance, including any risks, disputes and claims.
Innovation
Investments
Source: customer funded and internal research and development, acquisitions and joint ventures or other teaming arrangements.
Commercial cybersecurity market where 'Forcepoint' joint venture competes
Product Design Complexity
Numerous delay factors: unknown solutions, increase in new programs, competitor product acceptances.
No 'guarantee' of old/new market expansions, or acquisitions, joint ventures
Competitors
Bid protests from unsuccessful bidders on new program awards are becoming more frequent.
Bid protest delays the start of contract activities, delay earnings, and results in award decision being overturned, requiring a re-bid of the contract.
DoD are increasingly turning to commercial contractors, rather than traditional defense contractors, for information technology and other support work.
DoD increased use of Other Transaction Authority (OTA) contracts, it awards research and development work without all of the procurement requirements.
(OTA) contracts don't require procurement requirements that typically apply to DoD contracts, including justification of sole source awards.
U.S. government has been awarding more development programs due to changing U.S. government priorities.
Department of Homeland Security (DHS)
Entitled to limited indemnification from customers through contractual provisions.
SAFETY Act provisions of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 handicaps us.
Contractual insurance coverage or indemnification not adequate to cover all claims or liabilities.

LITIGATIONS
June 28th, 2019: Raytheon Accused Of Shorting Retirees On Benefits
Shortchanged retirees and violated the Employee Retirement Income Security Act by using outdated mortality rates to calculate retirement benefits.
Alternative annuity benefits for retirees would be 'actuarially equivalent' to their default benefits under the plan.
Plan used a 1971 mortality table and 7% interest rate to calculate those alternatives, this lowered the would be equivalent to the default benefits.
Raytheon also miscalculated the value of benefits under a subsidiary plan by using 1984 mortality rates and a 6% interest rate.
Alternatives must have same current value for multiple future cash payments, retirees lose part of their vested retirement benefits in violation of ERISA.
Alternative annuity benefits for retirees would be 'actuarially equivalent' to their default benefits under the plan.
Raytheon used 2014 mortality table in financial statements filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to show improvements to mortality.
Sept. 21, 2017: Peraton files suit against Raytheon
Raytheon breached its contract and miappropriated its trade secrets.
Peraton states it planned to team with Raytheon on two different contracts to support a national security agency.
Raytheon later elected to pursue the same two contracts independently as a competitor to Peraton and teamed with other competitors of Peraton.
Raytheon at first agreed to 'firewall' certain employees with access to Harris' trade secrets but then dropped the firewalls.
Additionally, Raytheon has failed to provide any assurances regarding the scope of its distribution of Peratonâ€™s trade secrets internally or externally.
Raytheon contends the agreement with Peraton was 'always expressly non-exclusive' and calls the lawsuit's claims 'baseless.'
Aug. 3, 2017: Raytheon wins end to whistleblower's $1 billion satellite lawsuit
Accusation: Overbilling the U.S. government on a contract for satellite sensors, nearly 1-1/2 years after a federal appeals court revived the case.
The False Claims Act case, which began in 2006.
Mismanaged subcontract to develop weather sensor for the National Polar-Orbiting Operational Environmental Satellite System (NPOESS), Northrop Grumman Corp - main contractor
Accusers fraud allegations remained too general, and his 'barebones' allegations regarding materiality also required dismissal. Complaint ammended five times.
Sept. 2, 2016: Fraud Claims Lead to Suit Against Raytheon
Accusation: Raytheon employees making $175K/year were misusing government resources and spending a fraction of the time required training Afghan troops.
Steven Kalch, Retired U.S. Army Lieutenant Colonel witnessed several instances of fraud, waste and abuse from 2012 to 2014.
He was fired in early 2014 over claims he tape-recorded U.S. Special Forces teams.
Trainers often putting in less than two hours per day performing duties outlined in the government contract.
He was instructed to put his suspicions in writing so it could be shared exclusively with Raytheon leadership.
Raytheon officials allegedly shared that document with the Afghan commander in question of stealing money.
Raytheon superior after the incident and was told 'not to put anything in writing in the future'.
Allegations of retaliation include the superior playing Christmas music endlessly in the office & placing singing Santa Claus directly behind Kalch's desk.
Nov. 3, 2015: Ex-employee sues Raytheon, alleging discrimination, retaliation
Accusation: Religious discrimination, race discrimination, national origin discrimination and retaliation.
Ammar Al-habash, a Muslim U.S. citizen born in Syria with two master's degrees, a Ph.D. in mathematics and top security clearance from U.S. government.
Al-habash was assigned tasks outside his competency level, prevented from completing applications for project clearance & passed over for promotions.
Al-habash heard Raytheon employees say Muslims and Arabs were 'all savages' and 'monsters,' and that 'we should bomb the hell out of all of them'.
Al-habash was later denied credit on a project on which he served as a consultant.
Received negative annual performance review + subjected to performance improvement plan after filing discrimination charge with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
May 13, 2004: Raytheon settles class action lawsuit for $410 million
Accusation: securities law violations in now-discontinued Raytheon units between October 1998 and October 1999.
Settlement includes a cash payment of $210 million and warrants for Raytheon stock valued at $200 million.
Raytheon said the lawsuit was meritless but that the company wanted to remove the uncertainty surrounding the outcome of the litigation.
Raytheon expects insurers to cover nearly (1/5)th of the $410 million settlement of lawsuit, even though the insurers had not approved the settlement.
Later that day, Raytheon reported one-off charges totaling $638 million and reduced earnings expectations.
Raytheon issued materially false and misleading statements regarding its financial performance.
Raytheon's Engineering & Constructors division ('RE & C') failed to disclose losses on major contracts.
RE & C misleadingly reported revenues on existing and anticipated contracts.
Raytheon failed to disclose that projects relating to the P-3 Orion aircraft and other defense equipment were over budget and behind schedule.
Raytheon failed to disclose that the Joint Primary Aircraft Training System was over budget and behind schedule.
The Securities action apparently settled in December 2004.
May 19, 2003: Insurance coverage dispute
Accusation: class action invoking section 10 the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 filed against Raytheon and several of its senior officers ('the Securities action').
The district court held that coverage was excluded under the prior and pending litigation exclusion clauses of both policies.
Coverage for both insurers is excluded under the Federal policy.
In 1999, Wall Street Journal article reported Raytheon, unbeknownst to investors, experienced cost overruns and was behind schedule on many defense-related contracts.
Later that day, Raytheon reported one-off charges totaling $638 million and reduced earnings expectations.

RE & C misleadingly reported revenues on existing and anticipated contracts.
Raytheon failed to disclose that projects relating to the P-3 Orion aircraft and other defense equipment were over budget and behind schedule.
Raytheon failed to disclose that the Joint Primary Aircraft Training System was over budget and behind schedule.
The Securities action apparently settled in December 2004.
May , 2003: Breach of fiduciary duty - Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974
Accusation: ERISA complaint alleged that the defendants were ERISA fiduciaries of the Plan.
Imprudent investment; failure to monitor other fiduciaries; misrepresentation + failure to disclose information to beneficiaries & failure to avoid conflicts of interest.
April 5, 1999: Raytheon Employees Resign in Wake Of Lawsuit Protesting Internet Postings
Accusation: Raytheon suspected some employees were talking behind its back on the Internet, the defense contractor took them to court.
21 people were using aliases to divulge company secrets, Raytheon got their real identities and the Web talk stopped.
Four of the workers quit, and the rest entered corporate 'counseling,' Raytheon dropped the suit and claimed victory.
Yahoo Chatterers used aliases like 'Rayman-mass' and 'RaytheonVeteran'.
Raytheon obtained subpoenas against Yahoo! and other Internet services like America Online, and Raytheon eventually learned all 21 names.
Employees exchanged gossip about the company and its executives, griped about Raytheon's stock price and discussed business deals, finances and staffing.
Sept. , 1994: UNITED STATES, Department of Justice SUES RAYTHEON CO. UNDER FALSE CLAIMS ACT
Accusation: Raytheon violated the False Claims Act by inflating the cost of a defense contract for a radar system.
Allegations relate to the PAVE PAWS system, a phased array radar system designed to detect incoming submarine-launched ballistic missiles.
Raytheon knowingly inflated its 'skill mix,' or ratio of higher to lower skilled employees, to increase the price of the contract.
When the US requested data on the skill mix Raytheon said it did not have the information in the form requested by the United States.
US alleged that Raytheon had the information in the requested form + they analyzed the skill mix proposal itself.
When the comparison was unfavorable, Raytheon instructed the employee who performed the analysis to 'bury' the information.
Cyber attacks and Cybersecurity
Cybersecurity threats include, but are not limited to, malicious software, attempts to access information, online extortion attempts.
Cybersecurity also includes disruption or denial of service attacks, insider threat attacks, and unauthorized access events to our data.
Recruitment and retention of qualified personnel
Significant percentage of Raytheon current workforce is nearing or eligible for retirement.
Hiring of new qualified technical, manufacturing, marketing, sales and management personnel.
Loss of key employees, failure to attract new qualified employees, delays in receiving security clearances, or delays in hiring key personnel.
Competition for personnel is intense and attracting or retaining qualified personnel with the requisite skills or security clearances is tough.
Geopolitical and economic factors
International business
In 2018, sales to customers outside the U.S. (including foreign military sales through the U.S. government) accounted for 30% of total net sales.
Factors: Geopolitical uncertainties, Volatility in worldwide economic conditions + volatility in energy prices, & changes in U.S. foreign policy.
Dec. 31, 2018, $2.3 billion of total contract value = $1 billion of sales for work performed to date + 850 million in advances from customers on these contracts.
Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (KSA) represents nearly 5% of Raytheon sales.
Raytheon had $500 million and $350 million of net contract assets and net contract liabilities, respectively, related to these contracts.
International sales: $1.4 billion (2018), $1.3 billion (2017+2016), British pounds and Australian dollars with the remainder in euros and Canadian dollars.
